Student Council names Spring Fair Chairs
by Mira Vadya
By unanimous vote, student
council members approved the
appointment of seniors Scott
Berger and Karen Weber as cochairmen for Spring Fair, which
will be held on the weekend of
April 6-8.
"They are experienced and enthusiastic," said Petrina Hsi.
Weber was photography chairman last year, and Berger also
worked on Spring Fair. Their
theme for this year will be "Circus '90."
Junior Paul Robinson was named as treasurer of Spring Fair by
a unanimous vote as well.
"He was the person most able
to get along with others," said
Hsi, in listing his qualifications.
The council will review the
MSE Symposium proposals by
next week's meeting, whichWill
be the last one of the semester.
In other council business, the
Athletics Committee has announced plans to sponsor a bus
trip to Madison Square Garden
for the basketball game between
Hopkins and NYU, to be held
during Winter Break. More information will follow next semester.
Applicants for the position of
driver for the third van the
University has recently purchased are being reviewed, and the
van will be put into service as

soon as possible. Van service will
be extended until 3 a.m.
The pay raise,for van drivers
has also been approved. Experienced drivers will now be
paid $6.00 an hour, while new
drivers will receive $5.50.
The new lights for the lower
quad have arrived, and will be
mounted on walls throughout the
area.
The council also discussed the
possibility of having a gate constructed across the "suicide
lane," as the number of students
hit each year while crossing
Charles Street is increasing.
A growing concern was voiced about the quality of service
provided by the Health Clinic.
Munia Mitra of the Student
Health Advisory Committee
reported that a number of students
were surveyed both coming into
and leaving the clinic within a
certain time period. Most
students appeared to be satisfied
with the attention they had
received.
Freshman Representative
Joshua Weiss argued that the
survey was biased, since it did not
cover the people who are unable
to schedule appointments.
Two of the major problems
Mitra cited were the clinic's
limited hours and the fact that
many students are unaware of the
clinic's policies. She reported that

the clinic has extended its hours
on Saturday from 9-12. A nurse
practitioner remains on call 24
hours a day for student emergencies, and can be reached through
the campus operator.
The Communications Committee reported progress on the issue
of a student-run radio station for
Hopkins. Council Secretary Jeff
Perlstein announced plans for a
new club in support of the radio
station.
He outlined plans for acquiring
a radio frequency, which included utilizing another station's empty air time, constructing a carrier
station through the dorms and
Wolman and McCoy,or hooking
into an FM cable line.
"The likelihood [of getting a
Hopkins station] depends on us,"
Perlstein said.
The biggest problem he sees is
the lack of "a physical place to
do it." Plans have been slated by
the University to renovate the
former WJHU control room in
Lazear and to convert it into a
convenience store.
Perlstein also mentioned that an
FCC licensing course will be offered during intersession for
anyone interested in obtaining a
radio license.
Bill Henry, Elections Commission chairman, reported that
special elections for the Executive
Board and the Young Trustees

will be held on March 6 and 13.
Class elections will be held on
April 17 and 24.
Student Support Services
reported that the Thanksgiving
shuttle made $100 with its service
to BWI Airport for students flying home for the holiday. There
will be no Christmas shuttle due
to the fact that students leave for
home on different days. Student
Support Services plans a mistletoe
sale in the upcoming weeks.
The Junior Class will be selling poinsettias outside Levering
next week. They will also sponsor a Holiday Study Break
December 12 in the Garrett
Room of the MSE Library.
Junior Class President Arthur
Yoon said that "fun" Christmas
cartoons and lots of munchies will
be featured at the holiday
gathering.
The Junior Class is also running an Owings Mills shopping
trip on Sunday, December 9,
which will be free of charge for
all members of the Junior Class.
The Sophomore Class reported
on their Thanksgiving can drive,
attributing much of its success to
the Sigma Phi Epsilon fraternity.
A total of about 75 cans were collected and donated to Sts. Philip
and James food camp.

history of marijuana use in the
United States.
In the 18th century, the stalks
of marijuana plants were used to
produce a type of rope called
hemp, which, in turn, was used
to manufacture paper and cloth,
Sir Walter Raleigh has the
dubious honor of having introduced marijuana to North
America. He imported the cannabis saliva plant with the hope
of establishing a lucrative market
for marijuana in the colonies,
Among the planters who were
first to try to grow marijuana in
the U.S. were Thomas Jefferson
and George Washington. They
were, however, unsuccessful in
their endeavors to cultivate the
plant.
Marijuana was not used in
America for psychoactive purposes until the early 1900's, said
Kelly.
The use of marijuana increased with the popularity of jazz

music, especially in the cities of
New York and New Orleans,
among blacks and Hispanics.
A turning point in the history
of marijuana use in America occurred in 1930 with the formation
of the Bureau of Narcotics. Kelly said that in 1930 the commissioner of the bureau, Harry Anslinger, was the first person to expose the health threat that marijuana use posed to the American
public.
Anslinger's propaganda campaign against marijuana use was
instrumental in the establishment
of the Marijuana Tax of 1937.
Although it did not outlaw use or
possession of marijuana, it did
discourage use.
To conclude the lecture, Kelly
addressed some of the medical
problems related to marijuana
use. If marijuana is smoked, the
onset of the effects is immediate;
if taken orally, onset occurs in
one-and-a-half to three-and-a-half
hours.
Marijuana use can cause panic
reactions, delirium, paranoia, and
mania. It can also exacerbate preexisting conditions like lung and
heart disease. Smoking marijuana
increases heart rate, lowers blood
pressure, and induces dilation and
irritation of the lungs.

I've come up with a new adjective for myself. Or rather I
haven't, my friend Karen did.
The word is WEARY.
It's perfect. In its most basic
definition, it means "tired," but
not in the everyday sense. A
Weary Person is exhausted not
just physically, but intellectually
and emotionally as well. The
Weary Person has run a gamut of
vastly different emotions in a
short time, and has exhausted his
or her emotive banks.
But that's just the surface
definition. Look at the word more
closely: W-E-A-R-Y. Wear—the
word is right inside. Wear, as in
the "wearing" away of one's
drive, one's excitement. Wear,
past tense "worn," as in "I'm
worn out." Wear, some readers
might say, as in "Yeah, Chris,
like wearing your heart on your
sleeve."
Yes. Why?
What makes us the Weary People? When we are born, our
parents spend the first five or six
years or so of our lives getting us
ready to go to school so that we
can learn, the idea being that after
five or six years, they are tired
of teaching us everything that we
have to know and want someone
else to pitch in. Fortunately for
them, the State requires such
delegation of responsibility.
In kindergarten, we are weaned onto the idea of structured
learning by first learning to tell
time (if we don't already know),
and then learning how to tell time
to play, and how to tell time to
work. And then our teachers
teach us.
And just as we are getting used to seeing our kindergarten
teacher's face (and often, it
seems, just as they learn our
names), the teacher is tired of us,
and we are given to another
teacher. We are sad for a while,
but we have a summer to get over
our loss, and come September of
first grade, our childish naivete
tells us, "Ah, well, perhaps this
teacher will like us better and
keep us longer.— All too soon,
however, we realize the error in
this.

It is around second grade that
we begin to see the pattern forming: we get new teachers every
year. The teachers tire of us every
yt
This may not always be the
case; in fact, I'm sure it isn't.
Teachers would probably rather
work with one group for a given
length of time. But to the young
student, it may easily be rationalized that the teacher is tired
of the student (or else just taken
away).
What is not thought of is that
the student also tires of the
classroom situation, but the student stays in the same environment for eight years, usually, and
then goes on to high school
That's what we're told.
"Grade school prepares you for
high school, and high school
prepares you for college, and college prepares you for life." And
we can see this. In grade school,
we are given more regimented
schedules, and we are taught increasingly difficult material. In
high school, we are given more
options of what to take, and our
extracurricular activities come to
mean more.
And then there's college. The
student takes full advantage. And
why? Because the student realizes
that studenthood is not eternal,
that soon they will be in the real
world—that is what they are supposed to be preparing for.
Wait. Preparing for? I thought
college prepared the student.
But it doesn't. And so, many
students, particularly the passionate, zealous students, overcompensate, trying to make the
most of themselves, if not always
the best of themselves. They try
to do everything. Frequently, all
at once.
And they get tired. Excuse me.
Weary.
There's one last thing I forgot
to mention about tired people.
When tired people wake up from
rest, they are back to normal.
When a Weary Person rests, he
puts everything in order, forgetting the trials, and accumulating
the wisdom.
The Weary Person may put in
more hours and more work, but
he wakes up better than ever.

There's never been a truer sequel than Robert
Zemeckis' "Back to the Future part II." It picks
up right at the end of—and includes scenes taken
directly from—the original "Back to the Future."
This is an unfortunate portent of things to come,
for many of the best moments in " Future part
II" come from its predecessor.
"Future part II" should really be shown with
the first film; there is no apparent development
of the characters from the first film. It's like watching the second night of a two-part television
mini-series whose first episode you saw four years
ago. Zemeckis and his collaborators are asking
a lot for viewers to remember that in 1955 Marty
McFly's mother called him "Calvin Klein," after
the moniker on his underwear.
Almost everyone from the original "Back to the
Future" is present for the sequel, and even those
who declined to return manage to make their
presence known. There's energetic Marty McFly
(Michael J. Fox), high-school nemesis Biff Tannen (Tom Wilson), nutty professor Doc Brown
(Christopher Lloyd), and Mrs. McFly (Lea
Thompson) past and present.
What "Future part II" is lacking is the delight
of its predecessor. Time travel is a seductive gimmick, but it can't replace characterization. (If it
had, maybe all movies would be about time
travel.) And if you are one of the dozen or so
Americans who has not seen "Back to the
Future," don't bother with the sequel. The new
film is fairly baffling on its own terms, even with
a knowledge of the original.
Doc Brown returns from the future in his
Delorean cum time machine, warning Marty that
his future offspring are in terrible trouble. So Marty, his girlfriend and future wife Jennifer
(Elizabeth Shue), and Doc jet into 2015 to save
this future family.
The future—at least Zemeckis' version of it—
is a jarring assault on the senses, and a disturbing one at that. Zemeckis isn't suggesting the
destruction of small-town America, but its complete commercialization. Instead of attending
church, future Americans worship the Pepsi god.
There are dueling video waiters (Ayatollah Kho-

meini and Ronald Reagan) at the "Cafe 80's,"
who were clearly inspired by Max Headroom.
This 2015 looks like something from a Steven
Spielberg movie; in fact, it is from a Spielberg
movie—the wunderkind director is "Future part
II"s executive producer. There are such selfaggrandizing futuristic nods here as a billboard
for "Jaws 19," directed by Spielberg's son Max.
But Zemeckis is no longer the Spielberg protege he once was; he stepped out of that shadow
with "Who Framed Roger Rabbit?" Regrettably,
"Future part 11" confirms that he's become a
master of the derivative gimmick. Zemeckis may
be the most creative storyteller in Hollywood, but
the sloppiness here is largely his responsibility.
Not surprisingly, all of the time travel rules that
applied to the past in the first film apply to the
future here. (For God's sake, Marty—the timespace continuum!) But Marty messes things up by
picking up an almanac of sports champions from
the last half of the 20th century. Biff is in the future
Hill Valley. looking old and still up to his
nefarious ways. He steals the sports almanac, and
taking the Delorean, he returns to 1955 to give
it to himself. Got that?
Biff circa 1955 uses the book to win piles of
money gambling, so when Marty and Doc Return
to 1985, Biff has turned Hill Valley into Gotham
City; it's an orgy of gambling and bikers. Mrs.
McFly is married to Biff—Marty's father was shot
dead years ago—and Biff reigns supreme.
Marty and Doc must return to 1955 to prevent
young Biff from keeping the book, while at the
same time not interfering with Marty from the
original "Back to the Future," who, you may
recall, has gone back to 1955 to make sure that
his parents meet and fall in love. You with me?
"Future Part II" may give some edgy viewers
the fatal Michael J. Fox overdose they had feared
for so long. In one 2015 scene, Fox's Marty plays
himself coming to the future, plays himself as an
old man in the future, and for no apparent reason,
plays his daughter in the future. Be warned: Fox
in drag looks like one of the transvestite men in
the short-lived sitcom "Bosom Buddies."
Zemeckis and writer Bob Gale truly seem to
want the audience to take time travel seriously,
but their presentation doesn't stand up to scrutiny.

I've come up with a new adjective for myself. Or rather I
haven't, my friend Karen did.
The word is WEARY.
It's perfect. In its most basic
definition, it means "tired," but
not in the everyday sense. A
Weary Person is exhausted not
just physically, but intellectually
and emotionally as well. The
Weary Person has run a gamut of
vastly different emotions in a
short time, and has exhausted his
or her emotive banks.
But that's just the surface
definition. Look at the word more
closely: W-E-A-R-Y. Wear—the
word is right inside. Wear, as in
the "wearing" away of one's
drive, one's excitement. Wear,
past tense "worn," as in "I'm
worn out." Wear, some readers
might say, as in "Yeah, Chris,
like wearing your heart on your
sleeve."
Yes. Why?
What makes us the Weary People? When we are born, our
parents spend the first five or six
years or so of our lives getting us
ready to go to school so that we
can learn, the idea being that after
five or six years, they are tired
of teaching us everything that we
have to know and want someone
else to pitch in. Fortunately for
them, the State requires such
delegation of responsibility.
In kindergarten, we are weaned onto the idea of structured
learning by first learning to tell
time (if we don't already know),
and then learning how to tell time
to play, and how to tell time to
work. And then our teachers
teach us.
And just as we are getting used to seeing our kindergarten
teacher's face (and often, it
seems, just as they learn our
names), the teacher is tired of us,
and we are given to another
teacher. We are sad for a while,
but we have a summer to get over
our loss, and come September of
first grade, our childish naivete
tells us, "Ah, well, perhaps this
teacher will like us better and
keep us longer.— All too soon,
however, we realize the error in
this.

It is around second grade that
we begin to see the pattern forming: we get new teachers every
year. The teachers tire of us every
yt
This may not always be the
case; in fact, I'm sure it isn't.
Teachers would probably rather
work with one group for a given
length of time. But to the young
student, it may easily be rationalized that the teacher is tired
of the student (or else just taken
away).
What is not thought of is that
the student also tires of the
classroom situation, but the student stays in the same environment for eight years, usually, and
then goes on to high school
That's what we're told.
"Grade school prepares you for
high school, and high school
prepares you for college, and college prepares you for life." And
we can see this. In grade school,
we are given more regimented
schedules, and we are taught increasingly difficult material. In
high school, we are given more
options of what to take, and our
extracurricular activities come to
mean more.
And then there's college. The
student takes full advantage. And
why? Because the student realizes
that studenthood is not eternal,
that soon they will be in the real
world—that is what they are supposed to be preparing for.
Wait. Preparing for? I thought
college prepared the student.
But it doesn't. And so, many
students, particularly the passionate, zealous students, overcompensate, trying to make the
most of themselves, if not always
the best of themselves. They try
to do everything. Frequently, all
at once.
And they get tired. Excuse me.
Weary.
There's one last thing I forgot
to mention about tired people.
When tired people wake up from
rest, they are back to normal.
When a Weary Person rests, he
puts everything in order, forgetting the trials, and accumulating
the wisdom.
The Weary Person may put in
more hours and more work, but
he wakes up better than ever.

The Latest 'Back to the Future'
An Ugly Portent of Things to
Come Namely, Next Summer
by Mark Friedman
There's never been a truer sequel than Robert
Zemeckis' "Back to the Future part II." It picks
up right at the end of—and includes scenes taken
directly from—the original "Back to the Future."
This is an unfortunate portent of things to come,
for many of the best moments in " Future part
II" come from its predecessor.
"Future part II" should really be shown with
the first film; there is no apparent development
of the characters from the first film. It's like watching the second night of a two-part television
mini-series whose first episode you saw four years
ago. Zemeckis and his collaborators are asking
a lot for viewers to remember that in 1955 Marty
McFly's mother called him "Calvin Klein," after
the moniker on his underwear.
Almost everyone from the original "Back to the
Future" is present for the sequel, and even those
who declined to return manage to make their
presence known. There's energetic Marty McFly
(Michael J. Fox), high-school nemesis Biff Tannen (Tom Wilson), nutty professor Doc Brown
(Christopher Lloyd), and Mrs. McFly (Lea
Thompson) past and present.
What "Future part II" is lacking is the delight
of its predecessor. Time travel is a seductive gimmick, but it can't replace characterization. (If it
had, maybe all movies would be about time
travel.) And if you are one of the dozen or so
Americans who has not seen "Back to the
Future," don't bother with the sequel. The new
film is fairly baffling on its own terms, even with
a knowledge of the original.
Doc Brown returns from the future in his
Delorean cum time machine, warning Marty that
his future offspring are in terrible trouble. So Marty, his girlfriend and future wife Jennifer
(Elizabeth Shue), and Doc jet into 2015 to save
this future family.
The future—at least Zemeckis' version of it—
is a jarring assault on the senses, and a disturbing one at that. Zemeckis isn't suggesting the
destruction of small-town America, but its complete commercialization. Instead of attending
church, future Americans worship the Pepsi god.
There are dueling video waiters (Ayatollah Kho-

meini and Ronald Reagan) at the "Cafe 80's,"
who were clearly inspired by Max Headroom.
This 2015 looks like something from a Steven
Spielberg movie; in fact, it is from a Spielberg
movie—the wunderkind director is "Future part
II"s executive producer. There are such selfaggrandizing futuristic nods here as a billboard
for "Jaws 19," directed by Spielberg's son Max.
But Zemeckis is no longer the Spielberg protege he once was; he stepped out of that shadow
with "Who Framed Roger Rabbit?" Regrettably,
"Future part 11" confirms that he's become a
master of the derivative gimmick. Zemeckis may
be the most creative storyteller in Hollywood, but
the sloppiness here is largely his responsibility.
Not surprisingly, all of the time travel rules that
applied to the past in the first film apply to the
future here. (For God's sake, Marty—the timespace continuum!) But Marty messes things up by
picking up an almanac of sports champions from
the last half of the 20th century. Biff is in the future
Hill Valley. looking old and still up to his
nefarious ways. He steals the sports almanac, and
taking the Delorean, he returns to 1955 to give
it to himself. Got that?
Biff circa 1955 uses the book to win piles of
money gambling, so when Marty and Doc Return
to 1985, Biff has turned Hill Valley into Gotham
City; it's an orgy of gambling and bikers. Mrs.
McFly is married to Biff—Marty's father was shot
dead years ago—and Biff reigns supreme.
Marty and Doc must return to 1955 to prevent
young Biff from keeping the book, while at the
same time not interfering with Marty from the
original "Back to the Future," who, you may
recall, has gone back to 1955 to make sure that
his parents meet and fall in love. You with me?
"Future Part II" may give some edgy viewers
the fatal Michael J. Fox overdose they had feared
for so long. In one 2015 scene, Fox's Marty plays
himself coming to the future, plays himself as an
old man in the future, and for no apparent reason,
plays his daughter in the future. Be warned: Fox
in drag looks like one of the transvestite men in
the short-lived sitcom "Bosom Buddies."
Zemeckis and writer Bob Gale truly seem to
want the audience to take time travel seriously,
but their presentation doesn't stand up to scrutiny.

coach Jerry Pfeifer resigned
November 21, following a second

again, you tend to lose support,"
said Pfeifer. "When you lose
support and have dissention, even
though you have a quality team,
it's nice if it can get a fresh start.
Someone new can erase the bad
records."

Hopkins in the early '60's,
Pfeifer returned to Hopkins in July, 1978, as an assistant football

compiled a 36-56-1 record in ten
years at the helm. For nine years,
he also served as an assistant
lacrosse coach.

of Hopkins intercollegiate football, Pfeifer enjoyed his finest
season, leading the Jays to a 7-2
mark. The seven wins tied the
school's record. After a 3-6
record the following year, Pfeifer
guided Hopkins to three consecutive winning seasons,
1983-85. Since then, the Jays
have won nine of 39 games.
"The players had high expectations for this season," Pfeifer
explained. "When we didn't
achieve them, they started pointing fingers in different directions, including at coaches. When
you're in a down cycle, you need
unity. People started to pull
away. That was the main reason
for our problems."

times, Pfeifer expressed optimism about the program he
leaves: "In terms of the team's
direction, I think it's very

positive. I see a young team returning with a lot of leadership. A
lot of our skill positions are now
as strong as they ever were. John
IGuglielmol, Jay [Simons), and
Dan Flynn have put the quarterback position out of the area of
concern and have made it a real
strength."
Quarterback inconsistency has
been the Achilles' heel of the
Blue Jays the past four seasons.
In 1985. Mark Campbell won the
Centennial Conference Most
Valuable Player award, completing 148 passes for 1,970
yards and 14 touchdowns. Since
then. no Hopkins quarterback has
earned 1,200 yards passing nor
thrown 10 touchdown passes in
a season. Midway through the
freshman
season,
1989
Guglielmo earned the starting
spot and increasingly showed
signs of the potential to end the
Jays' quarterback drought.

In nine years as a lacrosse
'assistant, Pfeifer helped guide
Hopkins to five NCAA national
championships. Last year, he
reduced his involvement in order
to devote more time to football
recruiting. "I don't think I will
be involved," Pfeifer stated
regarding the upcoming lacrosse
season.
Athletic director Robert Scott
praised Pfeifer's contribution to
Hopkins athletics. "We have
been fortunate to have had Jerry
with us because he is a man of integrity who has dedicated himself
to developing our athletes both on
the field and in their personal
lives. He has served Hopkins extremely well. I'm sorry to see
